translated: And if it is destroyed only by being an effect,

original: yat kāryaṃ tad avaśyaṃ nāśadharmakam iti pratipādayituṃ kārya /grahaṇam /
analyzed: yat kāryam tat avaśyam nāśa dharmakam iti pratipādayitum
translated: the mention of the effect is to demonstrate that whatever is an effect necessarily has the property of being destroyed.

original: āhetybhisambandhād dvitīyayā nirdeśaḥ /🔽samavāyabalād vṛttau tasyaikarūpatvād viśeṣābhāvo vivakṣitaḥ /
analyzed: āha iti bhisambandhāt dvitīyayā nirdeśaḥ  samavāya balāt vṛttau tasya eka rūpa tvāt viśeṣa abhāvaḥ vivakṣitaḥ
translated: And because of the connection with the word says, the second case is used.🔽When it occurs by the power of inherence, because it has one form, the absence of distinction is intended.

original: kṛtakatvānityatvayor ekatve kathaṃ bhede tasyopapatter ity āhadarśaneti / /
analyzed: kṛtaka tva anitya tvayoḥ ekatve katham bhede tasya upapatteḥ iti
translated: If being produced and being impermanent are the same, how is it that the absence of distinction is established in them? He says in perception, etc.

original: kṛtakatvānityatvayor dharmayor yo bhedaḥ pṛthaktvaṃ tasyāvabhāsaḥ sa vidyate yasyām sā ca sā kalpanā ceti tathā /
analyzed: kṛtaka tva anitya tvayoḥ dharmayoḥ yaḥ bhedaḥ pṛthaktvam tasya avabhāsaḥ sa vidyate yasyām sā ca sā kalpanā ca iti tathā
translated: That which has the appearance of the difference, the separateness, of the two properties of being produced and impermanence, that is such.

analyzed: dharma bhedam avabhāsayati iti vā tathā
translated: Or, it makes the difference of properties appear, so it is such.

original: sā ca sā kalpanā ceti tathā /
analyzed: sā ca sā kalpanā ca iti tathā
translated: And that is imagination, so it is such.

analyzed: ittham pada saṃskāram kṛtvā
translated: Having thus modified the words,

original: paścād abhūtvābhavandharmakabhūtvābhavandharmakavastudarśanabalotpannā ca sā ceti vigrahaḥ kāryaḥ
analyzed: paścāt a bhūtvā bhavan dharmaka bhūtvā bhavan dharmaka vastu darśana bala utpannā ca sā kṛtaka tva anitya tva dharma bheda avabhāsi kalpanā ca iti vigrahaḥ kāryaḥ
translated: then the analysis should be made: It arises from the power of seeing a thing that has the property of not having been and then becoming, and that has the property of having been and then becoming, and it is that.

analyzed: sā eva dvāram tena
translated: That itself is the door, the means, by which.

original: sādhakapramāṇābhāvād bādhakasadbhāvāc ca na tatkalpanā yuktimatīti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: sādhaka pramāṇa abhāvāt bādhaka sadbhāvāt ca na tad kalpanā yuktimatī iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that because there is no valid means of knowledge to establish it and because there is an objection, imagining it is not reasonable.

original: evaṃ sādhyasādhanabhāvopapattāv api tatkalpyatām /🔽yadi tad eva vyatiriktam anityatvādi tatsādhyām arthakriyāṃ prāptuṃ hātuṃ vārthibhiś
analyzed: evam sādhya sādhana bhāva upapattau api tat kalpyatām  yadi tat eva vyatiriktam anitya tva ādi tad sādhyām arthakriyām prāptum hātum vā arthibhiḥ
translated: Even if the relation of probandum and probans is possible in this way, let it be imagined.

original: cintyate tad api nāstīti darśayitum kalpayitvāpīti / vastvātmana
analyzed: cintyate tat api na asti iti darśayitum āha   kalpayitvā api iti vastu ātmanaḥ
translated: If that very separateness, impermanence, etc. is thought of by those who seek to attain or abandon the effect to be established by that, then that also does not exist. In order to show this, it is said even if imagined. The nature of the thing

analyzed: eva tad dharmi svarūpasya eva
translated: itself. Of the very nature of the substratum of that property.

analyzed: hāna upādāna viṣaya tayā cintya tvāt vicārya tvāt
translated: Because it is thought of as the object of abandonment and acceptance, because it is to be examined.

original: kathaṃ tasyaiva cintyatvam ity āha arthakriye /ti /
analyzed: katham tasya eva cintya tvam iti āha
translated: How is it to be thought of? He says: in terms of function.

original: kaiścintanīyatvam ity āha tadarthibhi /r iti /🔽tām arthakriyām arthayantīti tathā taiḥ /
analyzed: kaiḥ cintanīya tvam iti āha      tām arthakriyām arthayanti iti tathā taiḥ
translated: By whom is it to be thought of? He says: by those who desire that.🔽They desire that function, thus by them.

analyzed: arthakriyā ca tad āyattā atas eva upeksā apeyā
translated: And that function depends on that. Therefore, it is to be desired by those who are indifferent.

analyzed: rthinaḥ upāyam eva anusaraṃti iti
translated: Those who desire that follow only the means.

original: etad evacāryavacanena saṃspandayann āha tad i /ti /
analyzed: etat eva cārya vacanena saṃspandayan āha tat
translated: Connecting this very statement of the master, he says: that.

original: yasmād evam evaitan nānyathā tat tasmād uktam ācāryeṇa /
analyzed: yasmāt evam eva etat na anyathā tat tasmāt uktam ācāryeṇa
translated: Because it is just this, not otherwise, therefore it is said by the master.

analyzed: san hi sandhyā āvṛttiḥ sat vyāvṛttiḥ
translated: For the meaning of a word is existent, not non-existent, not both existent and non-existent, not different from the universal, not the same as the universal, not inexpressible as either the same or different, not non-different from the universal.

original: śabdārtha iti yaḥ pakṣabheda /s tena taṃ hetūkṛtya ye śabdārthānnāpahavatehnuvate
analyzed: śabda arthaḥ iti yaḥ tena tam hetūkṛtya ye śabda arthān na apahavata īhnuvate
translated: This is the difference of opinion. By that, making that the reason, those who do not deny the meaning of a word, who do not deny it,

original: tair vastv eva / śabdādikam eva /🔽vyāvṛttiḥ śabdārtha iti vādibhir apy arthāt vyāvṛttam eva vastu tathāpi prathā pra
analyzed: taiḥ vastu eva śabda ādikam eva  vyāvṛttiḥ śabda arthaḥ iti vādibhiḥ api arthāt vyāvṛttam eva vastu tathā api prathā pra
translated: by them, the thing itself, only that which is indicated by the word, etc.

original: tipādyata iti teṣām api vastucintanam /🔽athavā sadāpekṣyābhedādipakṣabhe
analyzed: tipādyate iti teṣām api vastu cintanam  athavā sadā apekṣya abheda ādi pakṣa bhe
translated: The meaning of a word is a negation, even by those who argue that the thing is negated by the meaning of the word, the manifestation is taught. Therefore, even for them, there is the thought of the thing.

original: dena sattvenāsattvena ca vastv eva cintyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: sattvena asattvena ca vastu eva cintyate iti arthaḥ
translated: Or else, by the difference of opinion regarding existence, non-existence, etc., in relation to the existent, the thing itself is thought of as existent or non-existent, this is the meaning.

analyzed: tasmā akasmā
translated: Therefore, from what?

original: d vastv eva cintyata ity āhāśaṃtyāśaṃ
analyzed: vastu eva cintyate iti āha aśaṃtyāśam
translated: He says in the object to indicate that the object is to be considered.

analyzed: kāyām atrahi iti uktam
translated: Here is said.

analyzed: hiḥ yasmāt
translated: Hi means because.

analyzed: atra vastuni
translated: Here means in the object.

original: yady apy atra vidhau sāmānyādirūpe vyāvṛttau ca prasajyapratiṣedhānmatidhātmani
analyzed: yadi api atra vidhau sāmānya ādi rūpe vyāvṛttau ca prasajya pratiṣedhāt mati dhā ātmani
translated: Although in this injunction, in the universal etc. form and in the exclusion, in the negation of the nature of cognition,

analyzed: phala udayaḥ na
translated: the arising of the result is not obstructed, still

original: kiṃ tathātvena cintyate ity ata āha artheti /
analyzed: kim tathātvena cintyate iti atas āha artha iti
translated: Is it considered thus? To this he says in the object.

analyzed: suratam ācaritum akṣamasya
translated: For one unable to engage in lovemaking, the third is the nature of the object.

original: rūpaṃ ca vairūpyaṃ ceti dvandvaikavadbhāvaḥ tatra kāminyā vṛṣasyantyāḥ kiṃ parīkṣayā / vimṛṣyāvadhāraṇena /
analyzed: rūpam ca vairūpyam ca iti dvandva eka vat bhāvaḥ tatra kāminyāḥ vṛṣasyantyāḥ kim parīkṣayā vimṛṣya avadhāraṇena
translated: Rūpa and vairūpya form a dvandva compound with singular ending. There, what is the use of examining the lustful woman who is in heat? By determining through deliberation,

analyzed: tad darśanaḥ
translated: seeing that,

original: p / nanu yadi vastutaḥ kṛtakatvānityatvayos tādātmyam tarhi vastunaḥ kṛtakatvaniścaye
analyzed: nanu yadi vastutas kṛtaka tva anitya tvayoḥ tādātmyam tarhi vastunaḥ kṛtaka tva niścaye
translated: Now, if in reality there is identity between being produced and being impermanent, then when the object is ascertained as being produced,

original: 'nityatvam apy aikātmyān niścitam eveti katham anumānāvatāra ity
analyzed: nitya tvam api aikātmyāt niścitam eva iti katham anumāna avatāraḥ iti
translated: impermanence is also ascertained due to the identity. So how is there room for inference?

analyzed: tasmāt
translated: Therefore,

analyzed: yasmāt tasya eva vastunaḥ tāpyam avaśya eṣitavyam tasmāt
translated: because that heat must necessarily be sought in that very object, therefore.

original: dṛṣṭā api bhāvāḥ kenacid ātmanā niścitās tadanyenātmanā anumānato niścīyanta iti saṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: dṛṣṭāḥ api bhāvāḥ kenacid ātmanā niścitāḥ tad anyena ātmanā anumānataḥ niścīyante iti saṃbandhaḥ
translated: The relation is: even though things have been perceived by some nature, they are ascertained by inference through another nature.

analyzed: dṛṣṭāḥ sākṣātkṛtāḥ bhāvāḥ śabda ādayaḥ dharmiṇaḥ
translated: Things such as sound that have been perceived, directly realized, are the subjects.

analyzed: kṛtaka tva ādinā rūpeṇa
translated: By some [nature], by the form such as being produced.

analyzed: kiṃbhūtena
translated: What kind of [nature]?

analyzed: tasmāt kṛtakāt anyat akṛtakam tasmāt vyāvṛttena
translated: From that which is produced, something else is not produced. From that,

original: kathañcid abhyāsapāṭavādiprakāreṇa tadanyenānityatvādinā tadrūpam anityarūpaṃ yan na bhavati tasmād vyāvṛttena / /
analyzed: kathañcid abhyāsa pāṭava ādi prakāreṇa tad anyena anitya tva ādinā tad rūpam anitya rūpam yat na bhavati tasmāt vyāvṛttena
translated: by some means such as practice and sharpness, through another [nature] such as impermanence, that form which is not impermanent, by excluding that,

analyzed: anena vyāvṛtti abhedena
translated: by this non-difference in exclusion, the difference

analyzed: rbhedaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: is shown.

original: kṛtakatveneva yadi tenāpy ātmanā te tadā niścetuṃ śakyāḥ katham anumānān niścīyanta ity āha / aniścīyamānā iti /
analyzed: kṛtaka tvena iva yadi tena api ātmanā te tadā niścetum śakyāḥ katham anumānāt niścīyante iti āha aniścīyamānāḥ iti
translated: If they can be ascertained by that nature just as by being produced, then how are they ascertained by inference? He says: being unascertained.

analyzed: aniścayaḥ eva kutas iti āha
translated: Why is there just non-ascertainment? He says:

original: bhrānter vibhramasya kāraṇaṃ nirantarasadṛśāparāparotpattir avidyā ca tasya sadbhāvāt /
analyzed: bhrānteḥ vibhramasya kāraṇam nirantara sadṛśa apara apara utpattiḥ avidyā ca tasya sadbhāvāt
translated: The cause of error, delusion, is the continuous arising of similar things, and ignorance. Because of the existence of that.

original: atha yadi tadānīm aniścitarūpeṇa samaṃ tasya niścitasya rūpasya pratibandho nāvasitas
analyzed: atha yadi tadānīm aniścita rūpeṇa samam tasya niścitasya rūpasya pratibandhaḥ na avasitaḥ
translated: Now, if at that time the form is unascertained, and the connection with that ascertained form is not determined,

original: tarhi katham asambaddhadarśanāt tanniścayo bhavitum arhatīty āśaṃkāyām anumānaṃ viśiṣṭam
analyzed: tarhi katham asambaddha darśanāt tad niścayaḥ bhavitum arhati iti āśaṃkāyām anumānam viśiṣṭam
translated: Then how can ascertainment of that be possible from the perception of what is unrelated? When this doubt arises, inference is distinguished.

analyzed: āha
translated: He says when ascertained.

analyzed: pramāṇa antarataḥ viparyaye bādhakāt pramāṇāt
translated: By another means of knowledge. From a means of knowledge that contradicts.

original: purovartī pūrabhāvī yasyānumānasya tasmāt / itis tasmāt tasya / vināśasyārthāntaranimittatayā tanmātrānanvayitve
analyzed: purovartī pūra bhāvī yasya anumānasya tasmāt itiḥ tasmāt tasya vināśasya artha antara nimitta tayā tanmātra ananvayi tve
translated: That which has the nature of being in front and being future, from that inference. Thus means from that. By the fact that destruction has a cause in something else, it does not follow from that alone.

original: yasmād evaṃbhūtā sattā tatsamavāyo vā anityatā ataeva / kāraṇāt ātmādāv evaṃbhūtasattāsamavāyayor abhāvād iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yasmāt evaṃbhūtā sattā tad samavāyaḥ vā anitya tā ataeva kāraṇāt ātma ādau evaṃbhūta sattā samavāyayoḥ abhāvāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Since existence or inherence in that is impermanence, for that very reason, because existence and inherence in that do not exist in the self and so on, this is the meaning.

original: athāstv evam kiṃ nacchinnam anena tāvadviśeṣaṇenāsmābhir vināśasyākhyātā
analyzed: atha astu evam kim na chinnam anena tāvat viśeṣaṇena asmābhiḥ atatsvabhāva tā vināśasya ākhyātā
translated: Now, if this is so, what is the point of this qualification? We have declared destruction to be momentary.

original: tāvataiva caritārthāḥ sma iti saugatamatam āśaṃkya svasiddhāntābhyāsavyāmohāpasmāraḥ
analyzed: tāvatā eva caritārthāḥ smaḥ iti saugata matam āśaṃkya sva siddhānta abhyāsa vyāmoha apasmāraḥ
translated: And we have accomplished our purpose with just that much, thinking this, the Sāṃkhya, overcome by the swoon of delusion due to the repetition of his own doctrine,

original: paraḥ prāha vināśa iti ca / iti /🔽itir vināśaśabdaṃ pratyavamṛṣati /
analyzed: paraḥ prāha vināśaḥ iti ca iti  itiḥ vināśa śabdam pratyavamṛṣati
translated: says destruction and so on.🔽Thus rejects the word destruction.

analyzed: tena vināśa śabdena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is by that word 'destruction'.

analyzed: prāgabhāva ādi bhedena bhāva abhāvasya anekavidha tvāt viśinaṣti pradhvaṃsa abhāva lakṣaṇam
translated: In order to distinguish it from the various kinds of existence and non-existence, such as prior non-existence, he specifies it as having the characteristic of destruction-non-existence.

original: kṛtakatvam a /pi bhavadbhis tadātmakam manyate tato 'yuktam atatsvabhāvatāpratipādanam
analyzed: kṛtaka tvam bhavadbhiḥ tad ātmakam eva manyate tatas yuktam a tad svabhāva tā pratipādanam
translated: You also consider that being produced has that as its nature, therefore it is not appropriate to establish it as not having that nature.

original: iti ca punar āśaṃkya para evāha kṛtakatvam iti tu /r bhinatti manyāmahe
analyzed: iti ca punar āśaṃkya paraḥ eva āha kṛtaka tvam iti   bhinatti manyāmahe
translated: And again suspecting this, the opponent says being produced, etc. He distinguishes it. We think

analyzed: iti abhisambandhyate
translated: This is connected.

analyzed: tathāvidhasya pradhvaṃsa abhāva lakṣaṇasya
translated: Of that kind, having the characteristic of destruction-non-existence.

analyzed: hetumat tayā virodhāt anupapatteḥ
translated: Because of contradiction, because of impossibility, due to having a cause.

original: kathaṃ punar virodha ity āha svayam i /ti /
analyzed: katham punar virodhaḥ iti āha svayam
translated: How is there contradiction? He says by itself, etc.

analyzed: evam bruvāṇaḥ tad upapatti anabhidhāna kāraṇam darśayati
translated: Speaking thus, he shows the reason for not stating the means of establishing it.

analyzed: pratipitsavaḥ
translated: Those who desire to know

analyzed: mudgara ādeḥ sakāśāt udaye tasya pradhvaṃsa abhāvasya
translated: Even if it arises from a hammer and so on, of that destruction-non-existence,

analyzed: bhāve vināśaḥ vastuni
translated: In existence, destruction is in a thing.

analyzed: an upayogāt a vyāpārāt  a tād artha sthyaḥ nid avasthyam ani
translated: Because of lack of use, because of inactivity.

original: tyatvaṃ tasya ca tadavasthatvāt katham anityatvam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tya tvam tasya ca tad avastha tvāt katham anitya tvam iti arthaḥ
translated: Non-eternality is not being in that state, not being in that state. And because of its being in that state, how can it be non-eternal? This is the meaning.

original: yadi nāma tadbhāve tatpūrvāvasthitarūpān na vicalati tathāpi tadviśeṣaṇau sattāsamavāyau tasyānityatā ity āha avicaliteti /🔽avicalitamanāpannānyathābhāvaṃ rūpaṃ yasya tasya sattāyām āha sāmānyasya samavāyasya caikatvenātmāder api tathābhāvo bhaved iti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: yadi nāma tad bhāve tad pūrva avasthita rūpāt na vicalati tathā api tad viśeṣaṇau sattā samavāyau tasya anitya tā iti āha avicalita iti  avicalitam an āpanna anyathābhāvam rūpam yasya tasya sattāyām āha sāmānyasya samavāyasya ca eka tvena ātma ādeḥ api tathābhāvaḥ bhavet iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Even if it does not deviate from the form it had in its previous state when it existed, still, its existence and inherence are its impermanence. Thus he says: That which does not deviate, i.e., does not become otherwise, has the form of existence. The meaning is that if existence and inherence are one, then the self and so on would also have that nature.

original: vināśa iti ca bhāvābhāvaṃ pradhvaṃsalakṣaṇaṃ manyāmaha iti yatpareṇoktaṃ tad avadyaṃ pratipādya kṛtakaṃ tv iti ca yad uktaṃ tad api
analyzed: vināśaḥ iti ca bhāva abhāvam pradhvaṃsa lakṣaṇam manyāmahe iti yat pareṇa uktam tat avadyam pratipādya kṛtakam tu iti ca yat uktam tat api dūṣayan  /
translated: And what the opponent said, that destruction is understood to be the absence of an existent characterized by destruction, that is a fault. And what was said, that it is produced,

analyzed: āha
translated: he says: in its own cause.

original: samavāyasyaikatvenātmāder api tathābhāvaprasaṅgenaivam anicchatopi na siddyatīty āśayaḥ /
analyzed: samavāyasya eka tvena ātma ādeḥ api tathābhāva prasaṅgena evam an icchataḥ api na siddyati iti āśayaḥ
translated: The idea is that even if one does not desire it in this way due to the consequence that the self and so on would also have that nature if inherence were one, it does not succeed.

original: amum evārthaṃ vidhimukhena sādhayann āha abhūtveti / varṇyate / lokaneti śeṣaḥ /🔽anenaitad darśayati vṛddhavyavahāro hi śabdārthaniścayabhūmiḥ /
analyzed: amum eva artham vidhi mukhena sādhayan āha a bhūtvā iti varṇyate lokanā iti śeṣaḥ  anena etat darśayati vṛddha vyavahāraḥ hi śabda artha niścaya bhūmiḥ
translated: Establishing this very meaning through the method of injunction, he says: not having existed is described. The rest is understood as by the world.🔽By this he shows that the usage of the elders is the basis for determining the meaning of words.

analyzed: kṛtaka tva śabdena ca evaṃvidhaḥ eva arthaḥ bhidhīyate vṛddhaiḥ iti
translated: And by the word produced, such a meaning alone is understood by the elders.
The refutation of prior non-existence and destruction was stated earlier by accepting their nature as qualifiers of that [existence].

original: saṃprati tu tām api vighaṭayann āha na ce /ti /
analyzed: saṃprati tu tām api vighaṭayan āha na
translated: But now, refuting even that, he says and it is not so [in the verse].

analyzed: etat ca pūrvam eva vyākhyāta prāyam
translated: And this has been almost explained before.

original: tad eva / abhūtvābhavanaṃ bhavitṛtvaṃ kṛtakatvam astu /🔽evaṃ tulyanyāyatayā vācā
analyzed: tat eva a bhūtvā bhavanam bhavitṛ tvam kṛtaka tvam astu  evam tulya nyāya tayā vācā
translated: That very [existence] is becoming after not having existed, the state of becoming, let it be the quality of being produced.

analyzed: bhavanam an icchataḥ nitya tā na siddhyati
translated: In the same way, by the same reasoning, for one who does not accept becoming, impermanence is not established.

original: bhūtvābhavanopagame vā sthirasvabhāvatayaivānityatāstv iti abhiprāyavatoktam asthiratvabhāvatā ce /ti /
analyzed: bhūtvā bhavana upagame vā sthira svabhāva tayā evā anitya tā astu iti abhiprāyavatā uktam asthira tva bhāvatā
translated: Or, if one accepts becoming after having existed, let impermanence be just by the stable nature [of existence]. With this intention, it is said and the state of non-stability [in the verse].

analyzed: yadi vā tasmāt an enanā
translated: Or, if by this [reasoning],

original: sthirasvabhāvataiva bhāvasyānumātavyeti yad utpattyabhidhānapūrvakam upasaṃhṛtiḥ tadabhiprāyeṇaivam uktam /
analyzed: sthira svabhāva tā eva bhāvasya anumātavyā iti yat utpatti abhidhāna pūrvakam upasaṃhṛtiḥ tad abhiprāyeṇa evam uktam
translated: the stable nature of existence itself is to be inferred, with this intention, the conclusion after stating the origination [of existence] is stated thus.

original: kṛtakatvasya vyabhicāraḥ / sādhyarahitā vṛttir anaikāntikatvam iti yāvat /
analyzed: kṛtaka tvasya vyabhicāraḥ sādhya rahitā vṛttiḥ anaikāntika tvam iti yāvat
translated: [The reason] being produced is inconclusive, that is, it is not universal, since it is present in what lacks the property to be proved.

analyzed: pratiṣedhyasya avaśyaṃbhāvi tvasya yat viruddham tena yat vyāpta ptam
translated: That which is pervaded by what is contradictory to the necessary existence of the negatee,

original: hetvantarāpekṣitvaṃ tasyopalabdhiḥ viruddhavyāptopalabdhir i /ti ca viruddhavyāptyoto🔽palabdhyaprasaṅga iti draṣṭavyam paropagamena pakṣadharmatāsiddheḥ /
analyzed: hetu antara apekṣi tvam tasya upalabdhiḥ viruddha vyāpta upalabdhiḥ ca  palabdhi aprasaṅgaḥ iti draṣṭavyam para upagamena pakṣa dharma tā siddheḥ
translated: The perception of what is pervaded by the contradictory is the perception of what is pervaded by the contradictory.🔽And the non-occurrence of the perception of what is pervaded by the contradictory should be seen. Because the establishment of the property of the subject is by the opponent's acceptance.

original: yatra hi vyāptir vāstavī pakṣadharmatā tu paropagamasiddhā sa prasaṅgahetuḥ /
analyzed: yatra hi vyāptiḥ vāstavī pakṣa dharma tā tu para upagama siddhā sa prasaṅga hetuḥ
translated: For where the pervasion is real but the property of the subject is established by the opponent's acceptance, that is a reductio ad absurdum argument.

original: yatra tu tritayaṃ pramāṇasiddhaṃ sa svatantro hetur ity āśaya eṣaḥ /
analyzed: yatra tu tritayam pramāṇa siddham sa svatantraḥ hetuḥ iti āśayaḥ eṣaḥ
translated: But where the triad is established by valid cognition, that is an independent reason. This is the intention.

original: tasya / ca hetoḥ tadāśrayasya / raṅgāśrayasya vastrādeḥ /
analyzed: tasya ca parimitasya hetoḥ tad āśrayasya raṅga āśrayasya vastra ādeḥ
translated: And of that reason, which is the basis of that, of the cloth etc. which is the basis of the color.

original: upadhātakaḥ pratyayo vidhurapratyayas tadupanipātena nāvaśyaṃbhāvitety anavaśyaṃ bhāvitety arthaḥ /
analyzed: upadhātakaḥ pratyayaḥ vidhura pratyayaḥ tad upanipātena na avaśyaṃbhāvitā iti anavaśyam bhāvitā iti arthaḥ
translated: The contributory condition is the contradictory condition. By the conjunction of that, it is not necessarily existent. The meaning is: it is not necessarily existent.

analyzed: punar śabdena rāgāt vināśam bhinatti
translated: By the word again, he distinguishes destruction from passion.

analyzed: vināśa hetu sannidheḥ prāk
translated: From the presence of its cause, from the presence of the cause of destruction, before.

analyzed: te eva upadhātakakā
translated: Those very contributory conditions

original: vināśakāḥ syus tataś ca sahetuko vināśaḥ siddha ity asyābhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: vināśakāḥ syuḥ tatas ca sa hetukaḥ vināśaḥ siddhaḥ iti asya abhiprāyaḥ
translated: would be the destroyers. And from that, destruction with a cause is established. This is his intention.

analyzed: takāraṇānām ca sva kāraṇa āyatta sannidhi tvāt iti eva saṃbaddhyate
translated: And. It is connected only as follows: because the presence is dependent on its own cause.

original: sannihitānām api vināśahetūnāṃ saṃbandhīnīmāni virodhīni p / śaktivibandhakāni yogipiśācādīni teṣām apy ānantyāt / /
analyzed: sannihitānām api vināśa hetūnām saṃbandhīni imāni virodhīni śakti vibandhakāni yogi piśāca ādīni teṣām api
translated: Even when the causes of destruction are present, these [causes] are related to [the object] as its opposites, as obstacles to its power, like the yogis, demons, etc. Since those [causes] are infinite.

analyzed: tad bhāve teṣām virodhinām sadbhāve
translated: In its existence, in the existence of those opposites.

analyzed: tad śakti pratibandhāt tasya nāśa hetoḥ śakteḥ upaghātāt
translated: Due to the obstruction of its power, due to the impairment of the power of that cause of destruction.

original: yadi te taddhetavas tair avaśyaṃ tatphalair bhāvyam ity āha i /ti /
analyzed: yadi te tad hetavaḥ taiḥ avaśyam tad phalaiḥ bhāvyam iti āha na avaśyam
translated: If those are its causes, then those effects must necessarily exist. He says iti.

original: itir hetau sāpekṣo 'pi / hi nidrādirvate haridrādivastre
analyzed: itiḥ hetau sa apekṣaḥ pi hi nidrā dirvate haridrā ādi vastre
translated: Iti is in the sense of cause, even when dependent. For example, sleep, etc. are in a cloth dyed with turmeric, etc.

original: dravyāpekṣopi kiṃ na syād iti praśne bauddhīyaṃ vacanaṃ syād / yadi tathopalabhyete /ti /
analyzed: dravya apekṣā upi kim na syāt iti praśne bauddhīyam vacanam syāt yadi
translated: Why should it not be dependent on substances? - if this is asked, the Buddhist's statement would be: If it is perceived in that way.

analyzed: tathā sarvagata tvena
translated: Tathā means in all places.

analyzed: yadi evam paraḥ
translated: If it is so, says the opponent.

original: anyathābhāva /sya kvacid abhavanasya śaṃkā saṃdehas tayā nādhātavyo / na karaṇīyo bhavadbhir iti ca prakaraṇāt /
analyzed: kvacid abhavanasya śaṃkā saṃdehaḥ tayā na ādhātavyaḥ na karaṇīyaḥ bhavadbhiḥ iti ca prakaraṇāt
translated: Anyathābhāvaśaṅkā means the doubt of non-existence somewhere. Na dātavyā means should not be done by you, according to the context.

analyzed: anena etat paraḥ darśayati sarvatra upalabdhasya anyathābhāva śaṃkā eva bhavataḥ prekṣāvataḥ
translated: The opponent shows: For an intelligent person like you, there can only be doubt about the possibility of a different state for something that is perceived everywhere.

original: na yuktā kevalam anena vyājena nūnaṃ parasiddhāntasyānavadyatayā manaḥkheda eva tvayā kriyata iti /
analyzed: na yuktā kevalam anena vyājena nūnam para siddhāntasya anavadya tayā manaḥ khedaḥ eva tvayā kriyate iti
translated: It is not proper for you to simply cause mental distress by this pretext, thinking that the opponent's doctrine is faultless.
What then? - says the proponent of the doctrine.

analyzed: sāmānya viśeṣa ākārābhyām praśnaḥ kiṃpunar śabdena nipāta a nipāta samudāyena
translated: The question is asked in the form of a general and specific statement by the particle kiṃ punar (what then), a combination of nipāta and nipāta.

original: samastavastuvistaravyāpī / sarvavastubāhulyavyāpī jñānāloko / yasya bhavataḥ sa tathā /
analyzed: samasta vastu vistara vyāpī sarva vastu bāhulya vyāpī jñāna ālokaḥ yasya bhavataḥ sa tathā
translated: The light of knowledge that pervades the entire vast range of things, that pervades the multitude of all things, belongs to you who have it. He is like that.

original: yathā tu vastuvistaraśabdasiddhis tathā purastād abhihitam /
analyzed: yathā tu vastu vistara śabda siddhiḥ tathā purastāt abhihitam
translated: But how the words vast range of things are established has been stated earlier.

original: tathābhāve / sarvavastudarśitve vā kasyaciddhetukṛto vināśo dṛṣṭaḥ /
analyzed: tathā bhāve sarva vastu darśi tve vā kasyacid hetu kṛtaḥ vināśaḥ dṛṣṭaḥ
translated: In that state, or in the case of seeing all things, the destruction of something is seen to be caused by a cause.

original: sarvasyaiva tādrūpyamanivāritam iti āha kasyacid i /ti /
analyzed: sarvasya eva tādrūpyam anivāritam iti āha kasyacid
translated: The same form is unavoidable for all. Therefore he says of something.

original: tur avadhāraṇe / kāraṇāntarādhīnotpattīnāṃ vastrarāgādīnām anyathāpi darśanād / apitṛteapītatve
analyzed: tuḥ avadhāraṇe     kāraṇa antara adhīna utpattīnām vastra rāga ādīnām anyathā api darśanāt
translated: Tu (but) is for emphasis. Because the production of things like the dyeing of cloth, which depend on other causes, is seen in other ways also, even without a father, even without being produced,

original: nāpy upalabdher hetoḥ upajātā /nyathātva śaṃkā prakaraṇād vināśasyābhāvasaṃdeho yasya puṃsas tathā san /
analyzed: nā api upalabdheḥ hetoḥ śaṃkā prakaraṇāt vināśasya abhāva saṃdehaḥ yasya puṃsaḥ tathā san
translated: the doubt of the arising of a different state is not due to the reason of perception. The doubt of the non-existence of destruction is in the case of a person who is like that.

analyzed: anena artha antara anubandhini sādhye kṛtaka tvasya āha
translated: By this (verse), (Dharmakīrti) shows that (the reason) being produced is inconclusive when the destruction that is related to another thing is to be proved.

analyzed: kṛtakam api ca ayam
translated: (He says), And this (destruction) is also produced... etc.

analyzed: tu sādhāraṇa anaikāntikam darśyati
translated: (In this verse), he shows that (the reason) is inconclusive because it is common to both the similar and dissimilar instances.

analyzed: pradhvaṃsa abhāvaḥ vivakṣitaḥ
translated: The words existence and non-existence refer to the destruction that is the absence of an existent thing.

analyzed: tasya eva sva niṣpattau apekṣita para vyāpāra tvena kṛtaka tvāt
translated: Because that (destruction) is produced by the activity of another thing that is required for its own production,

analyzed: tathātvena iṣta tvāt ca
translated: and because it is accepted to be so.

analyzed: nitya tā upagame kāraṇam āha tad vināśe iti
translated: (Dharmakīrti) states the reason for accepting (destruction) to be permanent: The destruction of that (destruction).

original: tasya bhāvābhāvasya pradhvaṃsalakṣaṇasya vināśe pradhvastasyonmajjanamāvirbhāvas tasya prasaṃgāt / prāpteḥ /
analyzed: tasya bhāva abhāvasya pradhvaṃsa lakṣaṇasya vināśe bhāvasya pradhvastasya unmajjanam āvirbhāvaḥ tasya prasaṃgāt prāpteḥ
translated: When there is the destruction of that existence and non-existence characterized by destruction, the reappearance, manifestation, of the destroyed (thing) would follow, because it would be attained.

analyzed: kim vā punar iti s
translated: What else could it be?

original: syād etan nityaṃ sattvādiprasaṅgena nāhetukaṃ vastunām ujjanam /
analyzed: syāt etat nityam sattva ādi prasaṅgena nā ahetukam vastunām ujjanam
translated: This (argument) may be: The arising of things is not without a cause, because of the consequence of (their) eternal existence, etc.

original: na ca ghaṭāder bhāvasya tadvināśavināśonvayavyatirekābhyāṃ kāraṇatvenāvagato 'pi tu kulālādir eva /
analyzed: na ca ghaṭa ādeḥ bhāvasya tad vināśa vināśaḥ nvaya vyatirekābhyām kāraṇa tvena avagataḥ tu kulāla ādiḥ eva
translated: And although the destruction of the destruction of an existent thing like a pot is understood to be the cause by positive and negative concomitance, it is only the potter, etc. (that are the cause).

original: tat kathaṃ vināśavināśe tadunmajjanamāsaṃjyamānamabhajamānaṃ na syād iti /
analyzed: tat katham vināśa vināśe tat unmajjanam āsaṃjyamānam abhajamānam na syāt iti
translated: How then could the reappearance of that (destruction of destruction) not occur, not be accepted, when it is not accepted?

analyzed: tat avadyam
translated: That (criticism) is indeed a fault.

original: tathāhi ghaṭābhāvavyāvṛttir p / eva ghaṭo ghaṭavināśaś ca ghaṭāṭa
analyzed: tathā hi ghaṭa abhāva vyāvṛttiḥ eva ghaṭaḥ ghaṭa vināśaḥ ca ghaṭāṭa
translated: For thus, the exclusion of the absence of a pot is just the pot, and the destruction of the pot is the exclusion of the absence of the pot.

original: bhāvavyāvṛttir iti ghaṭābhāvasyābhāve ghaṭarūponmajjanāsaṃjanaṃ jyāya eveti /
analyzed: bhāva vyāvṛttiḥ iti ghaṭa abhāvasya abhāve ghaṭa rūpa unmajjana asaṃjanam jyāyaḥ eva iti
translated: Therefore, in the absence of the absence of a pot, the appearance of the pot itself is certainly correct.

analyzed: atra eva upacaya hetum āha na
translated: Here itself, he states the reason for the increase, saying and not etc.

original: sa / nāśo 'hetuḥ san tasya / pradhvaṃsābhāvasya kathaṃjāyeta / janitum arhati /
analyzed: sa nāśaḥ hetuḥ san tasya pradhvaṃsa abhāvasya   janitum arhati
translated: That destruction, which is without a cause, how can it arise for that? It is fit to generate.

analyzed: saṃjāyate s
translated: It arises.

original: bhāṣānāṃ / vastūnām ayaṃ vināśākhyo dharma aikāntiko ' /vaśyaṃbhāvī /
analyzed: bhāṣānām vastūnām ayam vināśa ākhyaḥ dharmaḥ aikāntikaḥ
translated: This dharma called destruction is absolutely certain and inevitable for things.

original: darśayati naiva kṛtakatvaṃ nirviśeṣaṇaṃ sādhanam asmābhir abhidhīyate yenaivaṃ syāt kintu vastutvaviśeṣaṇānavaṇenāva
analyzed: anena etat darśayati na eva kṛtaka tvam nirviśeṣaṇam sādhanam asmābhiḥ abhidhīyate yena evam syāt kintu
translated: He shows that we do not state the reason being produced without qualification, by which it would be so. But rather, by stating the qualification being a real entity,

original: vicchinnaṃ tato vastutve sati yatkṛtakatvaṃ tadavaśyaṃbhāvināśam ity ārtha iti /
analyzed: vicchinnam tatas vastu tve sati yat kṛtaka tvam tad avaśyaṃbhāvi nāśam iti ārthaḥ iti
translated: the meaning is that whatever is produced, which is a real entity, that necessarily has destruction.

original: kutaḥ puna /r ityādinā siddhāntī pratividhatte kṣepe kimaḥ prayogān na kutaścid ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kutas ityādinā siddhāntī pratividhatte kṣepe kimaḥ prayogāt na kutaścid iti arthaḥ
translated: From But why? and so on, the proponent of the established view replies, From what? meaning why not use the argument?

original: etad i /ti bhāvānām avaśyabhāvī vināśa iti /
analyzed: etat bhāvānām avaśya bhāvī vināśaḥ iti
translated: This refers to the inevitable destruction of things.

original: teṣāṃ anyathātvasya / avināśitvasyānupalabdher etad avasitam iti prakaraṇāt /
analyzed: teṣām avināśi tvasya anupalabdheḥ etat avasitam iti prakaraṇāt
translated: Of their being otherwise. Because of the non-apprehension of non-destruction, this is concluded, due to the context.

analyzed: bhavan api vidyamānaḥ api
translated: Even if it exists, even if it is present,

original: ātmādeḥ / sattāyā anivartaka / ātmādyabhāvasyāsādhakaḥ katham anyatra / vastuṣu anyathābhāvam avināśitvaṃ nivartayati /
analyzed: ātma ādeḥ sattāyāḥ anivartakaḥ ātma ādi abhāvasya asādhakaḥ katham anyatra vastuṣu anyathābhāvam avināśi tvam nivartayati  /
translated: the soul, etc., the existence of which is not averted, which does not prove the non-existence of the soul, etc., how can it avert the being otherwise, the non-destruction, of other things?

analyzed: niṣedhayati
translated: It denies.

analyzed: ātma ādi upanyāsena ca etat darśayati
translated: And by mentioning the soul, etc., he shows this.

original: yady 'vināśāśitvābhāvaṃ sādhayati tarhi viśeṣābhāvād ātmādyanupalambhopi tadabhāvaṃ sādhayet /
analyzed: yadi vināśa āśi tva abhāvam sādhayati tarhi viśeṣa abhāvāt ātma ādi anupalambhaḥ api tad abhāvam sādhayet
translated: If it proves the non-existence of non-destruction, then, due to the absence of a specific reason, the non-apprehension of the soul, etc. would also prove that non-existence.

original: na cāyam apīti dṛṣṭāntavighaṭanaṃ parasyāśaṃkamāna āha tasye /ti /
analyzed: na ca ayam api iti dṛṣṭānta vighaṭanam parasya āśaṃkamānaḥ āha
translated: And this is not so. Anticipating the opponent's criticism of the example, he says of that and so on.

analyzed: tasya ātma ādeḥ ātmanaḥ tāvat rūpa rasa ādi pratyayānām eka aneka tva sādhakasya abādhita pratisandhāna viṣaya tva ādeḥ anumānāt
translated: Of that, of the soul, etc. As for the self, the proof of the oneness and manyness of the cognitions of form, taste, etc. is the object of unobstructed recollection, etc.

original: ādi /śabdasaṃgṛhītasya ca digādeḥ pūrvāparādipratyayāder anumānata iti buddhistham /
analyzed: ca diś ādeḥ pūrva apara ādi pratyaya ādeḥ anumānataḥ iti buddhi stham
translated: And the beginning of the word includes the inference of the east, etc. and the cognitions of east, west, etc. This is understood.

analyzed: itinā vaktavyasya akāraḥ kathitaḥ
translated: By the word iti, the form of what is to be said is stated.

analyzed: tatra api anumāne tad sattva sādhake
translated: And in that inference, which proves the existence of that,

analyzed: anyathābhāvasya
translated: The non-existence of something else is not established by the mere non-perception of that [thing].

original: nanu yasyānupalabdhis tasyābhāva evety abhidhātari ko 'yam upālambhaḥ /
analyzed: nanu yasya anupalabdhiḥ tasya abhāvaḥ eva iti abhidhātari kaḥ yam upālambhaḥ
translated: But when you say that the non-existence of something is only due to the non-perception of it, what is this accusation against us?

analyzed: vipakṣe api hetoḥ vṛtti adarśaṇe bhāva siddhi avirodhāt
translated: Because there is no contradiction in establishing non-existence by not seeing the occurrence of the reason in the dissimilar class.

original: ātmādes tv evāsiddhā tato nābhāvasiddhir iti /
analyzed: ātma ādeḥ tu eva asiddhā tatas na abhāva siddhiḥ iti
translated: But the self and so on are not established, so non-existence is not established in that case.

original: sādhūktaṃ bhavatā kevalaṃ tatrāpī /tyādi bruvato 'bhiprāyo na samyagvyajñāyi /
analyzed: sādhu uktam bhavatā kevalam bruvataḥ bhiprāyaḥ na samyak vyajñāyi
translated: You have spoken well. But when you say only there too, the intention is not fully understood.

analyzed: ayam khalu asya āśayaḥ
translated: This is his intention.

original: tāvaddhetor vipakṣe 'nīkṣaṇaṃ na kṣamate abhāvaṃ vibhāvayituṃ /
analyzed: tāvat hetoḥ vipakṣe nīkṣaṇam na kṣamate abhāvam vibhāvayitum
translated: To begin with, not seeing the reason in the dissimilar class is not able to make one understand non-existence.

original: yāvad yady annopalabhyate tat tan nāstīti na sidhyati /
analyzed: yāvat yadi anna upalabhyate tat tat na asti iti na sidhyati
translated: And as long as it is not perceived, it is not established that it does not exist.

original: sati caivamātmādyanupalabhyamānam iti pramāṇapratikṣiptaṃ kathaṃ anumānasya viṣayaḥ syāt /
analyzed: sati ca evam ātma ādi anupalabhyamānam iti pramāṇa pratikṣiptam katham anumānasya viṣayaḥ syāt
translated: And if the self and so on are thus not perceived, being rejected by valid cognition, how could they be the object of inference?

original: tad uktaṃ vyāpto hetor anāśraya iti /
analyzed: tat uktam vyāptaḥ hetoḥ anāśrayaḥ iti
translated: As it was said, The reason is not the basis of the pervasion.

original: yadi vānupalambha eva pratibandhaśūnyaḥ kevalo 'nupalambho deśakālaviprakṛṣṭeṣu kathaṃ tathābhāvam avabodhayet /
analyzed: yadi vā anupalambhaḥ eva pratibandha śūnyaḥ kevalaḥ deśa kāla viprakṛṣṭeṣu katham tathābhāvam avabodhayet
translated: Or if non-perception alone, devoid of restriction, is merely non-perception in distant places and times, how could it make one understand the state of affairs in that way?

original: yatas tena siddhivipakṣā hetuvyāvṛttir ātmādeḥ sattvam anumāpayed iti /🔽prayogabhaṅgyaiva / prasaṅgenā /nuṣaṅgena prastāveneti yāvat /
analyzed: yatas tena siddhi vipakṣā hetu vyāvṛttiḥ ātma ādeḥ sattvam anumāpayet iti  prayogabhaṅgyā eva    prastāvena iti yāvat
translated: Because by that, the exclusion of the reason which is adverse to the establishment of the soul etc. would be inferred as existence.🔽By the very formulation of the argument. By implication. By extension. By occasion. This is what is meant.

original: p / sādhyadṛṣṭāntadharmiṇoḥ samānaḥ / sadṛśo hetusadbhāvalakṣaṇo dharmaḥ / pratipādyatayā yasya / prayogasyāsau sadharmā /
analyzed: sādhya dṛṣṭānta dharmiṇoḥ samānaḥ sadṛśaḥ hetu sadbhāva lakṣaṇaḥ dharmaḥ pratipādya tayā yasya prayogasya asau sadharmā
translated: The property that is similar, i.e., has the characteristic of the presence of the reason, in the probandum and the example, is that which is to be conveyed. Of which argument, that is the one with the property.

original: samānasyeti yogavibhāgāt samānasya pakṣādiṣv iti vaktavye parigrahād vā sa bhāvas tasya bhāvo / bhavato 'smād abhidhānapratyayāv iti kṛtvā
analyzed: samānasya iti yogavibhāgāt samānasya pakṣa ādiṣu iti vaktavye parigrahāt vā sa bhāvaḥ tasya bhāvaḥ smāt abhidhāna pratyayau iti kṛtvā
translated: Because of the division of compounds, although it should be said of the similar one in the position etc., it is included. Or that existence is of that. Considering that the designation and understanding come from this.
It is a particular form.

original: tayor eva visadṛśo / hetusadbhāvāsadbhāvalakṣaṇo dharmaḥ pratipādyatayā yasya tasya bhāvaḥ / aśeṣasya sādhyetaradharmiṇaḥ sādhyadharmiṇaḥ
analyzed: tayoḥ eva visadṛśaḥ hetu sadbhāva asadbhāva lakṣaṇaḥ dharmaḥ pratipādya tayā yasya tasya bhāvaḥ aśeṣasya sādhya itara dharmiṇaḥ sādhya dharmiṇaḥ
translated: The property that is dissimilar to those two, i.e., has the characteristic of the presence and absence of the reason, is that which is to be conveyed. Of which, that existence is of the entire probandum and other subjects. Of the probandum subject.

original: sādhyadharmaṇovānyatra sarvatra sādhye hetor vyāptir vivakṣitā /
analyzed: sādhya dharmaṇā u vā anyatra sarvatra sādhye hetoḥ vyāptiḥ vivakṣitā
translated: The pervasion of the reason is intended everywhere else, in all the probandums, except in the probandum.

original: na tu sādhyadharmaṇo 'nyatra dṛṣṭāntadharmiṇi pravṛttena sarvopasaṃhāreṇa gṛhyamāṇā vyāptir bahirvyāptiḥ tasyā nirāsaḥ / /
analyzed: na tu sādhya dharmaṇaḥ nyatra dṛṣṭānta dharmiṇi pravṛttena sarva upasaṃhāreṇa gṛhyamāṇā vyāptiḥ bahirvyāptiḥ tasyāḥ nirāsaḥ  /
translated: But the pervasion that is grasped by the occurrence of the reason in the example subject, which is different from the subject of the property to be proved, by a universal concomitance, is external pervasion. The refutation of that [is as follows].

original: nanu ca sattvalakṣaṇe sādhyadharmiṇy api viparyaye bādhakapramāṇavṛttyāpi vyāptir grahītuṃ śakyata iti /
analyzed: nanu ca sattva lakṣaṇe svabhāva hetau sādhya dharmiṇi api viparyaye bādhaka pramāṇa vṛttyā api vyāptiḥ grahītum śakyate iti
translated: But it is possible to grasp the pervasion even in the subject of the property to be proved, which has the characteristic of existence, by the occurrence of a valid means of knowledge that excludes the contrary.

original: naitad apekṣayā hetor anyatra vṛttyapekṣayā kiṃcid yenedam āsajyeta /
analyzed: na etat apekṣayā hetoḥ anyatra vṛtti apekṣayā kiṃcid yena idam āsajyeta
translated: This is not relevant to the reason's occurrence elsewhere, by which this [external pervasion] could be imposed.

original: kiṃtu kāryahetoḥ sarvasya svabhāvahetuviṣayasya cāvaśyam anyatra praa🔽vṛttir apekṣaṇīyā /
analyzed: kiṃtu kārya hetoḥ sarvasya svabhāva hetu viṣayasya ca avaśyam anyatra  vṛttiḥ apekṣaṇīyā
translated: But in the case of all causal reasons and of those whose domain is reasons based on the nature of things, the occurrence elsewhere is necessarily to be taken into account.

original: tadarthaṃ anyatrāanuvṛttir ity āśaṅkitam iti kin na bhavān /
analyzed: tad artham anyatra a anuvṛttiḥ iti āśaṅkitam iti kim na bhavān vyācaṣṭe
translated: Therefore, the suspicion that the occurrence elsewhere is to be taken into account is not to be rejected.

original: ācāryasya ca yathā ghaṭādaya / ity udāharaṇadarśanāt
analyzed: ācāryasya ca yathā ghaṭa ādayaḥ iti udāharaṇa darśanāt
translated: And because the teacher has shown examples such as pots, etc.,

original: tu tvadīyaṃ vyākhyānam apavyākhyānaṃ lakṣyata iti nirbhartsanāmāśaṅkyāsyācāryasyānyadṛśam🔽abhiprāyam udghāṭayann āha yathā ghatādaya / iti /
analyzed: tu tvadīyam vyākhyānam apavyākhyānam lakṣyate iti nirbhartsanām āśaṅkya asya ācāryasya anya dṛśam  abhiprāyam udghāṭayan āha yathā ghata ādayaḥ iti
translated: your explanation appears to be a misinterpretation. Suspecting this reproach, he reveals the teacher's other view, saying like pots, etc.

analyzed: yasya puṃsaḥ
translated: Of which person.

analyzed: kim punar tatra smṛti ādhāna artham dṛṣṭānta vacanam
translated: What is the purpose of stating an example there for the purpose of implanting memory?

original: na tu dṛṣṭāntamātrapratipādanārtham ity āha dṛṣṭānte / /
analyzed: na tu dṛṣṭānta mātra pratipādana artham iti āha
translated: But it is not for the purpose of teaching the example alone, he says: In the example...

original: anena puruṣaviśeṣaṃ prati etad ācāryeṇeti nāsmadvyākhyānasya kiṃcid avadyam iti darśayati /
analyzed: anena puruṣa viśeṣam prati etat ācāryeṇa iti na asmad vyākhyānasya kiṃcid avadyam iti darśayati
translated: By this, he shows that this was said by the teacher to a particular person, and that there is no fault in our explanation.

original: vibhaktivipariṇāmena sambandham eva sarvasminn i /ty anena darśayati /
analyzed: vibhakti vipariṇāmena sambandham eva sarvasmin anena darśayati
translated: By the change of case endings, he shows the connection in everything with this.

analyzed: bahis bahis vyāptiḥ tām
translated: External pervasion is pervasion outside.

analyzed: te nirastāḥ bhavanti iti sambandhaḥ
translated: Those are removed. This is the connection.
Even though... is a collection of indeclinable particles for accepting the statement of a particular.

analyzed: sādhana dharmasya sādhya dharmeṇa anvaya darśana mātreṇa iti
translated: To that extent... is merely seeing the concomitance of the property to be established with the property to be proved.

original: asya / sādhanadharmasya tathābhāvasya sādhyenānvīyamānatvasya abhāvāt / /🔽pratibandham antareṇa tadabhāve 'pi tadabhātadbhā
analyzed: asya sādhana dharmasya tathābhāvasya sādhyena anvīyamāna tvasya abhāvāt  pratibandham antareṇa tad abhāve pi tad abhā tad bhā
translated: Because of the absence of the existence of that property to be established, which is being followed by the property to be proved.

analyzed: vā avirodhāt iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The point is that without a restriction, even in its absence, there is no contradiction in its existence.

analyzed: itiḥ hetau
translated: Iti is in the sense of a reason.

analyzed: tasya pratibandha sādhakasya
translated: For the purpose of remembering that proof which establishes the restriction.
The subject is qualified by the property to be proved. The subject is sound etc.

original: tasyāḥ / sādhyadharmaviśiṣṭadharmipratipatteḥ /🔽vyāptipradarśanapūrvake pakṣadharmapradarśane 'bhidhāya pakṣadharmapradarśanapūrvake vyāptipradarśane 'py āha tatpūrvikāyāṃ ce /ti /
analyzed: tasyāḥ sādhya dharma viśiṣṭa dharmi pratipatteḥ  vyāpti pradarśana pūrvake pakṣa dharma pradarśane bhidhāya pakṣa dharma pradarśana pūrvake vyāpti pradarśane pi āha tad pūrvikāyām
translated: Of that. Of the cognition of the subject qualified by the property to be proved.🔽Having stated the indication of the property of the subject preceded by the indication of the pervasion, he also says and in that preceded etc.🔽In the pervasion preceded by that, preceded by the indication of the property of the subject,

original: tatpūrvikāyāṃ pakṣadharmapradarśanapūrvikāyāṃ vyāptau / p / pradarśyamānāyāñ🔽ceti śeṣaḥ sarvopasaṃhāreṇa plavamānākārāyāḥ pratipatter ubhayatrāviśeṣānmukhabhedamātreṇaitad
analyzed: tad pūrvikāyām pakṣa dharma pradarśana pūrvikāyām vyāptau  ca iti śeṣaḥ sarva upasaṃhāreṇa plavamāna ākārāyāḥ pratipatteḥ ubhayatra aviśeṣāt mukha bheda mātreṇa etat
translated: when the pervasion is being indicated,🔽the rest is to be supplied. The cognition that floats with the inclusion of all is the same in both cases. This is stated

analyzed: uktam iti avaseyam
translated: merely as a difference in the method, it should be understood.

analyzed: tad smṛtaye
translated: For the sake of remembering that,

original: sādhyanirdeśaḥ pratijñā / tasyāh prayogaḥ / prayuktiḥ sa nadarśitaḥ / sādhyanirdeśo na kṛta ity arthaḥ /🔽pratyakṣa /grahaṇaṃ pramāṇopalakṣaṇaṃ draṣtavyaṃ tena tabhisrāyāṃ rātrau prāktanādiviprakṛṣṭe deśe karpūrorṇādigarthagandha
analyzed: sādhya nirdeśaḥ pratijñā tasya āh prayogaḥ prayuktiḥ sa sādhya nirdeśaḥ na kṛtaḥ iti arthaḥ  pramāṇa upalakṣaṇam draṣtavyam tena tabhisrāyām rātrau prāktana ādi viprakṛṣṭe deśe karpūra ūrṇā diś artha gandha
translated: the statement of the probandum is the thesis. The employment of that, the application, is not shown. The meaning is that the statement of the probandum is not made.🔽The word perception should be seen as an illustration of a means of knowledge. Therefore, in that night which is covered by darkness, the smell of camphor, wool etc.

analyzed: anumānataḥ niścitya agni viśeṣam anuminvataḥ saṅgrahaḥ
translated: is ascertained by inference in the distant place of the previous day etc., and even when inferring a particular fire, it is included.
The word 'only' shows that the purpose is to demonstrate the result.

analyzed: na upadarśitaḥ
translated: It is not shown.

original: atrārthitaiva karṇam āgatya buddhisthaṃ prakāśayati ya piśācī sā kila karṇapiśācikā / /
analyzed: atra arthitā eva karṇam āgatya buddhi stham prakāśayati piśācī sā kila karṇapiśācikā
translated: Here, the request itself comes to the ear and reveals what is in the mind - that she is indeed a demoness, and that demoness is the ear demoness.
The ascertainment, the determination, of the inferential mark which has the nature of the property of the subject, concomitance, and non-concomitance.

analyzed: itiḥ hetau
translated: The word 'iti' is in the sense of reason.

analyzed: upahasati adhirohati
translated: He laughs at it, and mounts it.

original: kim upahasatīty āha yat tad i /ti lokoktiś caiṣā /
analyzed: kim upahasati iti āha yat tat loka uktiḥ ca eṣā
translated: Why does he laugh at it? He says 'that' - this is a colloquial expression.

original: kathaṃ tatspardhāsyocyata ity āha tat tulyatvād i /ti /
analyzed: katham tad spardhā asya ucyate iti āha tat tulya tvāt
translated: How is it said to be rivaling that? He says 'because it is similar to that'.

analyzed: asya anumātuḥ
translated: Of him. The inferrer.

analyzed: kramasya samāna adhikaraṇa ṣaṣṭhī eva vā
translated: Of the sequence. Or even with the genitive case in apposition.

original: tadvacanasye /tyādinā pūrvaṃ svayaṃ kāraṇam abhidhāya ācāryoktaṃ kāraṇaṃ darśayituṃ paraṃ praśnenopakramayati kasmād i /ti /
analyzed: pūrvam svayam kāraṇam abhidhāya ācārya uktam kāraṇam darśayitum param praśnena upakramayati kasmāt
translated: Having stated the reason himself earlier with the words 'of that statement' and so on, the teacher begins the question to the opponent in order to show the reason stated by the opponent with the words 'why' and so on.

original: yadi pratijñāprayoge 'pi sā śaṅkā kiṃ tenety āśaṅkya para evāha anitya / ityādi /
analyzed: yadi pratijñā prayoge sā śaṅkā tarhi kim tena iti āśaṅkya paraḥ eva āha anityaḥ ityādi
translated: If there is that doubt even in the statement of the thesis, what is the use of it? Anticipating this doubt, the opponent says 'non-eternal' and so on.

original: tadātunā / pratijñāprayogapakṣaṃ viśinaṣṭi asati sādhyanirdeśa / ity evābhisambadhyate /
analyzed: tadātunā pratijñā prayoga pakṣam viśinaṣṭi asati iti eva abhisambadhyate
translated: Now, he distinguishes the thesis-statement position: This is connected with 'when there is no statement of the probandum'.

original: hetuś ca viruddhaś ca anaikāntikaś ca teṣāṃ pratītiḥ / niścayo na syāt /
analyzed: hetuḥ ca viruddhaḥ ca anaikāntikaḥ ca teṣām pratītiḥ niścayaḥ na syāt
translated: And the reason would be contradictory and inconclusive, there would be no ascertainment of them.

analyzed: idam eva dūṣaṇam tena samuccitam
translated: This very fault is combined by him.

analyzed: atra eva dūṣa antaram api samuccinvan āha
translated: Here, also combining another fault, he says:

analyzed: hetoḥ
translated: And of the reason.

analyzed: sva pakṣa viśeṣam darśayan āha
translated: Showing his own position, he says:

analyzed: tu
translated: But if there is.

original: yavate /ti nipātaḥ kintv etasyārthe vartamāno atropapatteḥ /
analyzed: nipātaḥ kintu etasya arthe vartamānaḥ atra upapatteḥ
translated: The particle yavat, meaning 'but', is used in the sense of 'however', because it is appropriate here.

analyzed: tasmin tasmin iva tadvat
translated: In that, it is bound to that, as if in that, like that.

original: viṣayaḥ sādhyalakṣaṇa upasthāpyate / upanīyate yene /ty arthakathanam etat /
analyzed: viṣayaḥ sādhya lakṣaṇaḥ upasthāpyate upanīyate artha kathanam etat
translated: The object characterized by the probandum is presented, is brought, by which. This is the explanation of the meaning.

analyzed: upasthāpyate yena puruṣeṇa asau tathā
translated: By which person the object is presented in that way.

original: viṣayasya tatheti tu vigrahaḥ /🔽tenānirdiṣtaviśeṣeṇa kenacid vinā / kathaṃ punas tena
analyzed: viṣayasya tathā iti tu vigrahaḥ  tena a nirdiṣṭa viśeṣeṇa kenacid vinā katham punar
translated: But the analysis is 'of the object in that way'.

original: sādhyam upasthāpyata ity āśaṃkāyāṃ yojyaṃ pratijñādvāreṇeti / /
analyzed: sādhyam upasthāpyate iti āśaṃkāyām yojyam
translated: Without that by which the particular is not stated, by whom? How again is the probandum presented by that? When there is doubt, it should be connected with 'by means of the thesis'.

analyzed: tu na asti s
translated: But it does not exist.

analyzed: pratijñā vacana dvārena iti
translated: By means of the words of the thesis, it is.

analyzed: evam tāvat anena vyākhyātam
translated: Thus far it has been explained by him.

analyzed: kecid punar anyathā api etat vyācakṣate
translated: But some explain this differently.

original: upasthāpyate prakāśyate yena / vacanena tena vinā / /
analyzed: upasthāpyate prakāśyate yena vacanena tena vinā
translated: By which it is presented, illuminated, by that speech without which,

original: ayam api prameyasyopadarśanam antareṇa / ity atropadarśanaśabdena vacanam eva vyākhyāsyati na tu puruṣam /
analyzed: ayam api prameyasya upadarśanam antareṇa iti atra upadarśana śabdena vacanam eva vyākhyāsyati na tu puruṣam
translated: This also, without the presentation of the object to be known, here the word 'presentation' will be explained as speech itself, but not as a person.

original: tad api atrāgnimānayaṃ sāgnir ayam ityādirūpeṇānirdiṣṭaviśeṣaṃ vivakṣitam ity ataḥ kenacid ity uktam iti kāryiṇo /rthinaḥ /
analyzed: tat api agniḥ atra agnimān ayam sa agniḥ ayam ityādi rūpeṇa anirdiṣṭa viśeṣam vivakṣitam iti atas kenacid iti uktam iti kāryiṇaḥ
translated: That also, which is not indicated by the form 'this has fire, this has fire', etc., is intended here, therefore 'by someone' is said by the litigants.

analyzed: arthi tvam ca anvaya brāhmaṇa aprāpti ādinā draṣṭavyam
translated: And the state of being a litigant should be seen as not being obtained by the Anvaya Brahmana, etc.

analyzed: mūlyam niṣkrayam mṛgayate prārthayate
translated: The price, the ransom, he seeks, he desires.

analyzed: itas tatas pārvaṇa śrāddha ādi bhojī dvijaḥ parvabrāhmaṇaḥ
translated: The twice-born who eats at various Parvana Sraddha etc. is a Parva Brahmana.

original: amum eva dṛṣṭāntaṃ vivṛṇvann āha yathe /ti /
analyzed: amum eva dṛṣṭāntam vivṛṇvan āha
translated: Explaining this very example, he says 'as' etc.

original: dakṣiṇā / atra prakaraṇād bhojanānantaraṃ dānaṃ draṣṭavyam /
analyzed: dakṣiṇā atra prakaraṇāt bhojana anantaram dānam draṣṭavyam
translated: The fee, here the giving after the meal should be seen from the context.

analyzed: anyadā artha viśeṣa aprāpti kālāt anyasmin kāle
translated: At another time, at a time other than the time of not obtaining a particular purpose.

original: prārthanāpūrvakam itas tato bhojanaśīlataurdhvarathyikaḥparvabrāhmaṇasadṛśasya caitad viśeṣaṇaṃ caraṇam /
analyzed: prārthanā pūrvakam itas ca etat viśeṣaṇam caraṇam
translated: The conduct of one who is in the habit of eating here and there after making a request is like that of a Parva Brahmana.

analyzed: atra ādi grahaṇāt upanayana samāvartana ādi parva saṅgrahaḥ
translated: In at Sraddha and so on, by the word and so on, the Parva ceremonies such as Upanayana, Samvartana, and so on are included.

original: naitad vacanaṃ tasya sambhāvyata iti taṃ viśeṣayann āha śraddhālu /m iti /
analyzed: na etat vacanam tasya sambhāvyate iti tam viśeṣayan āha    iti
translated: This statement is not possible for him, so specifying him, he says to one who has faith.

analyzed: śraddhālum śraddhāvantam
translated: One who has faith, who is endowed with faith.

original: anena śraddhānuviddham evārthitvaṃ kāryaśabdena vārtikakṛto vivakṣitam iti darśayati /
analyzed: anena śraddhā anuviddham evā arthi tvam kārya śabdena vārtika kṛtaḥ vivakṣitam iti darśayati
translated: By this, he shows that the author of the Vartika intended the word request to be imbued with faith.

analyzed: ghṛtapuraḥ khādya viśeṣaḥ tam prati
translated: To one who has ghee in front, a special food, to him.

original: sopi mahyaṃ pracuro dātavya iti viruktena darśayati /
analyzed: saḥ api mahyam pracuraḥ dātavyaḥ iti viruktena darśayati
translated: He also shows by the word much that much should be given to me.
Silver, which is made of less silver than much, is more.

analyzed: dakṣiṇā yathā ādau ṇa ādau
translated: In the south, in the beginning of the word dakshina, in the beginning of the word dakshina.

analyzed: ca prāyeṇa rūpakeṇa vyavahāraḥ
translated: And generally, there is usage by metaphor.

analyzed: abhisambandhāt dvitīyā
translated: The second case is by connection, because it gives.

analyzed: tena evaṃvādinā parvabrāhmaṇena
translated: By that, by the Parva Brahmana who speaks thus.

analyzed: aurdhvarathikaḥ s
translated: The one who performs the funeral rites.

analyzed: rūpakam s
translated: The metaphor.

analyzed: dadāsi
translated: You give.

original: nanūktam etad yathā parārthe 'numāne liṅgaṃ parasmād eva pratyeyam iti tatpunas tvayā na apahastitam iti āśaṃkāyāṃ yadasmadvacanād apī /ty
analyzed: nanu uktam etat yathā para arthe numāne liṅgam parasmāt eva pratyeyam iti tat punar tvayā na apahastitam iti āśaṃkāyām
translated: But has this not been said: In inference for others, the reason must be known by the other person alone. That has not been refuted by you. When there is doubt about this, it is said: Even from our statement...

analyzed: uktam
translated: This is what has been said.

original: tad vyākhyātuṃ kiṃ ce / kiṃ ceti ca bruvāṇo niyataṃ vaktavyāntarasamuccaye /
analyzed: tat vyākhyātum kim kim ca iti ca bruvāṇaḥ niyatam vaktavya antara samuccaye
translated: To explain that, it is said: And if... The word and is used to include another statement that is certain.

original: arthād ācāryasyābhipreta iti darśayati na tv asyaiva vaktavyāntarasamuccayārthaḥ kiṃca /śabdaprayogo ghaṭate /🔽yad api bravīṣītyāder asmadvacanād apītyācāryavacanāntaravyākhyānaparatvasya vyaktatvāt /
analyzed: arthāt ācāryasya abhipretaḥ iti darśayati na tu asya eva vaktavya antara samuccaya arthaḥ ghaṭate  yat api bravīṣi ityādeḥ asmad vacanāt api iti ācārya vacana antara vyākhyāna paratvasya vyakta tvāt
translated: It shows that it is implied by the teacher, but the use of the word and by itself does not make sense to include another statement.🔽As for what you say, it is clear that the statement beginning with from our statement... is about explaining another statement by the teacher.

original: athavāyaṃ nipātānipātasamudāyaḥ kiñcaśabdo 'sya vivakṣitaḥ kintu apiśabdasyārthe /
analyzed: athavā ayam nipāta a nipāta samudāyaḥ vivakṣitaḥ kintu cakāraḥ apiśabdasya arthe
translated: Or this collection of particles and non-particles is intended for the word and, but in the sense of the word also.

original: tena kim apīty uktaṃ bhavati /🔽tato 'yaṃ vākyārtho yad api kim api bravīṣīti /
analyzed: tena kim api iti uktam bhavati  tatas yam vākya arthaḥ yat api kim api bravīṣi iti
translated: Therefore, it is said and if.🔽So the meaning of the sentence is and if you say anything.

analyzed: evam ca bruvatā loka uktiḥ anukṛtā iti
translated: By saying this, it is an imitation of common speech.

analyzed: tad vacanasya liṅga vacanasya
translated: Of that statement, of the statement of the reason.

original: anusariṣyati / tad eva liṅgam iti prakṛtatvāta /
analyzed: anusariṣyati tat eva liṅgam iti prakṛta tvāt
translated: It will follow. That itself is the reason, because it is the subject.

analyzed: tra adhyeṣa āmantraṇe
translated: The word 'aṅga' here means 'request'.

original: kiṃ /śabdaḥ sāmānyataḥ praśne punaḥ / śabdas tu viśeṣataḥ /
analyzed: sāmānyatas praśne punar śabdaḥ tu viśeṣataḥ
translated: The word 'kim' is for a general question, but the word 'punar' is for a specific question.

original: tenāyam artho p / evādhyeṣya sāmānyato viśeṣataś caiva pṛcchāma iti /
analyzed: tena ayam eva adhyeṣya sāmānyatas viśeṣataḥ ca eva pṛcchāmaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the meaning is just this: we request and ask both generally and specifically.

analyzed: upahāse ca iyam adhyeṣaṇā prakaraṇāt draṣṭavyā
translated: And this request should be seen as a joke, from the context.

analyzed: yatas asmad vacanāt api
translated: Because even from our words, you can understand the meaning.

original: ādi /śabdād vaidharmyavat prayogasya hetuviruddhānaikāntikānāṃ hetos trairūpyasya ca grahaṇaṃ /
analyzed: vaidharmya vat prayogasya hetu viruddha anaikāntikānām hetoḥ trairūpyasya ca grahaṇam
translated: From the word 'ādi', the use of similarity and dissimilarity, the three forms of the reason such as contradictory and inconclusive, are included.

analyzed: prāk sādharmya vaidharmya vat prayogayoḥ hetu viruddha anaikāntikānām
translated: The teacher has already mentioned the understanding of the words. The use of similarity and dissimilarity, the three forms of the reason such as contradictory and inconclusive,

original: hetos trairūpyasya ca svarūpapratītir vivakṣitety abhipretya sādharmyavat prayogadeḥ
analyzed: hetoḥ trairūpyasya ca svarūpa pratītiḥ vivakṣitā iti abhipretya sādharmya vat prayoga deḥ
translated: and the three forms of the reason, with the intention that the nature of understanding is intended. He explains that the understanding of the use of similarity is

analyzed: pratītiḥ iti vyācaṣṭe
translated: explained as 'understanding'.

analyzed: atas eva krameṇa etat sarvam darśayiṣyate
translated: For this very reason, all this will be shown in order.

original: nanu kim avaśyaṃ prāptiḥ pakṣadharmasya ca prayogo yenaivam ucyamānaṃ śobhate ity āśaṃkyāha evaṃ manyata / iti /
analyzed: nanu kim avaśyam prāptiḥ pakṣa dharmasya ca prayogaḥ yena evam ucyamānam śobhate iti āśaṃkya āha evam manyate iti
translated: But why is it necessary to state the attainment and the property of the subject in the argument, by which it is said in this way? Anticipating this doubt, he says 'thus he thinks'.

original: tad anityam iti uktaṃ / iti yojayitvā kiṃ so 'vagamyata ity aśaṃkāyāṃ pakṣadharmavacane satī /ti yojyam /
analyzed: tat anityam iti uktam iti yojayitvā kim tanmātra uktyā saḥ vagamyate iti aśaṃkāyām pakṣa dharma vacane yojyam
translated: That is said to be impermanent. Having thus connected [the verse], when there is doubt about what is understood, it should be connected with when the property of the subject is stated.

original: yat kacid i /tyādi tupūrvam eva kṛtavyākhyānam /
analyzed: yat kacid eva kṛta vyākhyānam
translated: As for somewhere and so on, that has already been explained before.

analyzed: anumāna kālaḥ eva atra vyavahāra kālaḥ
translated: Here, at the time of inference, the time of usage is intended.

analyzed: na pakṣa ādi saṅketa grahaṇa apekṣā vastu gatiḥ iti anuvartate
translated: It does not depend on grasping the convention of the subject and so on. The course of things continues.

analyzed: iti ācārya vasubandhum
translated: By the teacher's feet means by the teacher Vasubandhu.

analyzed: nāntarīya kārya darśanam tad vidaḥ numānam
translated: Inference is the perception of that which is invariably concomitant - this is the meaning of this [verse].

original: yorthaḥ kiṃcid antareṇa na bhavati sa nāntarīyakaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ ṛthaḥ kiṃcid antareṇa na bhavati sa nāntarīyakaḥ
translated: The meaning that does not exist without something is invariably concomitant.

original: atra ca sāmarthyādyam artham antareṇa na bhavati tan nāntarīyaka iti grāhyam /🔽sa cāsāvarthaś ceti tadā tasya darśanam /
analyzed: atra ca sāmarthya ādyam artham antareṇa na bhavati tat nāntarīyakaḥ iti grāhyam  sa ca asau arthaḥ ca iti tadā tasya darśanam
translated: And here, it should be understood that the meaning that does not exist without that by capacity is invariably concomitant.🔽And that is the meaning. The perception of that is [the perception of] that.

original: darśanena ca viṣayiṇā viṣayasya tasyaiva nirdeśaḥ /
analyzed: darśanena ca viṣayiṇā viṣayasya tasya eva dṛśyamānasya nirdeśaḥ
translated: And by the perception, which is the subject, that very object is indicated.

original: tena niścīyamāna evāsau parokṣārthahetur bhavatīti darśitam /
analyzed: tena niścīyamānaḥ eva asau parokṣa artha hetuḥ bhavati iti darśitam
translated: Thus, it is shown that it becomes the cause of the hidden meaning only when it is being ascertained.

original: tadvida / iti tannāntarīyakatāṃ yo vetti tasyety arthaḥ /
analyzed: tad vidaḥ iti tad nāntarīyakatām yaḥ vetti tasya iti arthaḥ
translated: By one who knows that means by one who knows that invariable concomitance. That is the meaning.

analyzed: ca anumānam uktam
translated: And because it is inference by reason of being a means of knowledge, it is said to be inference.

analyzed: gamaka rūpa mātrasya svarūpam prakaraṇe
translated: Thus, he shows the nature of mere the form of the means of knowledge in the chapter called the section on injunctions.

analyzed: tatra api lakṣaṇe
translated: Even there, in the definition by Ācārya.

analyzed: uddyota kara prabhṛtibhiḥ
translated: By some, by Uddyotakara and others.

original: kutaḥ punar asaṃta eva doṣās taiḥ kīrtyanta āśaṃkāyāṃ yojyaṃ svaprajñe /ti /
analyzed: kutas punar asaṃtaḥ eva doṣāḥ taiḥ kīrtyante iti āśaṃkāyām yojyam
translated: But from where are those faults, which do not exist, proclaimed by them? In doubt, one should apply one's own wisdom.

analyzed: sva prajñāyāḥ aparādhaḥ doṣaḥ tasmāt
translated: The fault is the transgression of one's own wisdom.

original: tu /r avadhārayati /🔽tathā hyuddyotakareṇa kilānumānasūtravārtike 'pare tu bruvate nāntarīyakārthadarśanaṃ tadvido 'numānam iti Nyāyavā / p /
analyzed: avadhārayati  tathā hi uddyota kareṇa kila anumāna sūtra vārtike pare tu bruvate nāntarīyaka artha darśanam tad vidaḥ numānam iti
translated: But, he determines.

original: paṭhitvā tasyārthaṃ mātrayā vivṛttyaiva atrārthagrahaṇam atiricyata iti mātrayaiva dūṣaṇam uktvā punar vipañcitam nāntarīyakārya iti
analyzed: paṭhitvā tasya artham mātrayā vivṛttyā eva atra artha grahaṇam atiricyate iti mātrayā eva dūṣaṇam uktvā punar vipañcitam nāntarīya kāryaḥ iti
translated: For thus, it is said, Uddyotakara, in the Anumānasūtra commentary, after quoting Others say: Inference is the seeing of an effect that is invariably concomitant with it by one who knows that relation, and having refuted it by saying The word 'effect' is superfluous in the definition of inference, he again elaborates: The compound 'naantarīyakârtha'

original: samāsapadam etat /🔽tatra yadi samāso nāntarīyakasyārtha iti /
analyzed: samāsa padam etat  tatra yadi ṣaṣṭhī samāsaḥ nāntarīyakasya arthaḥ iti
translated: is this.🔽If in that, the meaning of the compound is 'invariably concomitant,'

analyzed: na anyantarīyakam tāvat kṛtaka tvam
translated: then 'produced' is not invariably concomitant.

analyzed: tasya arthaḥ dharmaḥ prayojanam vā
translated: Its meaning is a property or purpose.

original: yadi tāvad dharmaḥ kṛtakatvasyārthaḥ /🔽sattvaprameyatvābhidheyatvādy anumānaṃ prāptam /
analyzed: yadi tāvat dharmaḥ kṛtaka tvasya arthaḥ  sattva prameya tva abhidheya tva ādi anumānam prāptam
translated: If the meaning of the word 'kṛtaka' is 'having the nature of being produced',🔽then inference of existence, measurability, expressibility, etc. would be obtained.

analyzed: atha prayojanam anitya tva pratipattiḥ hetuḥ prāptaḥ
translated: If the purpose is the understanding of impermanence, then a reason would be obtained.

analyzed: atha bahuvrīhiḥ nāntarīyakaḥ rthaḥ yasya iti
translated: If it is a bahuvrīhi compound meaning 'that which has an invariable meaning',

analyzed: tatra api kṛtaka tvam
translated: then in that case, 'being produced'

original: nāntarīyakaṃ tad yasya sa hetuḥ prāptaḥ /
analyzed: nāntarīyakam tat yasya sa hetuḥ prāptaḥ
translated: would be obtained as the reason for that which has it as an invariable consequence.

original: tac ca kṛtakatvaṃ ghaṭādeḥ p / vā /
analyzed: tat ca kṛtaka tvam ghaṭa ādeḥ śabdasya anitya tvasya vā
translated: And that 'being produced' is of a pot, etc. or of sound.

analyzed: yadi ghaṭa ādeḥ
translated: If it is of a pot, etc.,

analyzed: ghaṭa ādiḥ hetuḥ prāptaḥ
translated: then a pot, etc. would be obtained as the reason.

analyzed: anityaḥ śabdaḥ ghaṭāt  atha śabdasya
translated: Sound is impermanent because of a pot.🔽If it is of sound,

analyzed: śabdaḥ hetuḥ prāpnoti
translated: then sound would be obtained as the reason.

original: anityaḥ śabdaḥ śabdāt /🔽aathānityatvasyasādhyasādhanakṛtakatvaṃ dharmas tathāpy anityaḥ śabdo 'nityatvād iti prāpnoti /
analyzed: anityaḥ śabdaḥ śabdāt  dharmaḥ tathā api anityaḥ śabdaḥ nitya tvāt iti prāpnoti
translated: Sound is impermanent because of sound.🔽If the property of 'being produced' is for the purpose of impermanence, then it would be obtained that sound is impermanent because of impermanence.

original: athānityatvasyārthaḥ kṛtakatvam iti /🔽sarvathā kṛtakatvam anityatve na hetuḥ syāt /
analyzed: atha anitya tvasya arthaḥ kṛtaka tvam iti  sarvathā kṛtaka tvam anitya tve na hetuḥ syāt
translated: If the meaning of 'impermanence' is 'being produced',🔽then in any case 'being produced' would not be a reason for impermanence.

analyzed: atha nāntarīyakaḥ ca asau arthaḥ ca iti
translated: If it is both an invariable consequence and a meaning,

analyzed: tathā api asamarthaḥ samāsaḥ viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya niyama abhāvāt
translated: then even so, the compound is not effective, because there is no restriction of qualifier and qualified.

original: ubhayapadavyabhicāre sati samānādhikareṇā bhavati nīlotpalavat nīlaśabdasyānekārthapravṛttatvād utpalaśabdasya ca tathābhāvāt sāmānādhikaraṇyaṃ 🔽bhavati /
analyzed: ubhaya pada vyabhicāre sati samāna adhikareṇā bhavati nīla utpala vat nīla śabdasya aneka artha pravṛtta tvāt utpala śabdasya ca tathā bhāvāt sāmānādhikaraṇyam  bhavati
translated: When there is deviation of both words, there is co-reference like blue-lotus, because the word 'blue' applies to many meanings and the word 'lotus' has that nature, there is co-reference.

original: na punar iha nāntarīyakatve ity uka ity u
analyzed: na punar iha nāntarīyaka tve iti ukaḥ iti u
translated: It is not so here, as stated.

original: vyabhicāro 'rtho 'nartha iti yenārthagrahaṇaṃ samarthaṃ syāt /🔽ekapadavyabhicāro 'pi dṛṣṭaṃ sāmānādhikaraṇyaṃ pṛthivī dravyam iti cāśaṃkyoktam anyathā taṃtat
analyzed: vyabhicāraḥ rthaḥ na arthaḥ iti yena artha grahaṇam samartham syāt  eka pada vyabhicāraḥ dṛṣṭam sāmānādhikaraṇyam pṛthivī dravyam iti ca āśaṃkya uktam anyathā taṃ tat
translated: Deviation is the meaning, whether beneficial or not, by which the word 'meaning' could be valid.

analyzed: pṛthivī dravyam iti
translated: Co-reference is seen even with deviation of one word, as in 'earth is substance', and fearing that, it is said otherwise, as 'that earth is a substance'.

original: atrobhayapadavyabhicāraḥ /🔽pradhānāṅgabhāvasya bhedena pṛthivīśabdena dravyam apy ucyate pṛthvītvañ ca /
analyzed: atra ubhaya pada vyabhicāraḥ  pradhāna aṅga bhāvasya bhedena pṛthivī śabdena dravyam api ucyate pṛthvī tvam ca
translated: Here there is deviation of both words.🔽The relation of primary and secondary is stated separately, as 'earth' denotes both substance and earthness,

original: dravyaśabdena ca dravyaṃ dravyatvañ ca ata evobhayapadavyabhicārāt pṛthivī dravyam iti yuktam uktam /
analyzed: dravya śabdena ca pradhāna aṅga vivakṣayā dravyam dravya tvam ca atas eva ubhaya pada vyabhicārāt pṛthivī dravyam iti yuktam uktam
translated: and 'substance' denotes both substance and substantiveness. Therefore, because of deviation of both words, it is rightly stated that 'earth is a substance'.

original: iha punar na yuktaṃ nāntarīyakadakārthadarśanam iti /
analyzed: iha punar na yuktam nāntarīyaka daka artha darśanam iti
translated: But here it is not right to say 'seeing the meaning that is invariably concomitant'.

original: kasmād arthapratyāyanārthatvāc chabdaprayogasya arthapratyāyanārthaṃ hi śabdasya prayogam icchanti /
analyzed: kasmāt artha pratyāyana artha tvāt śabda prayogasya artha pratyāyana artham hi śabdasya prayogam icchanti
translated: Why? Because the use of words is for the purpose of conveying meaning. For they desire the use of words for the purpose of conveying meaning.

analyzed: nāntarīyakaḥ iti ca ukte rthaḥ gamyate
translated: And when it is said inseparable, the meaning is understood.

analyzed: atas na yuktaḥ rtha śabdaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the word meaning is not appropriate.

original: tadvida iti na yuktam naivānyathānāntīyaka / iti /
analyzed: tad vidaḥ iti na yuktam na eva anyathā ānāntīyakaḥ iti
translated: One who knows that is not appropriate, nor is inseparable in another way.

original: na hi nāliker advīpavāsino dhūmadarśanān nāntarīyaka iti jñānam asti /
analyzed: na hi nālikeḥ a dvīpa vāsinaḥ dhūma darśanāt nāntarīyakaḥ iti jñānam asti
translated: For those who live on an island other than Nālikera do not have the knowledge that it is inseparable from seeing smoke.

original: atas tadvida ity api na vaktavyam /
analyzed: atas tad vidaḥ iti api na vaktavyam
translated: Therefore, one who knows that should not be said either.

original: Nyāyavā / p / asanta eva doṣa iti bruvāṇaś cāyam evābhivam abhipraiti /
analyzed: nyāyavān asantaḥ eva doṣaḥ iti bruvāṇaḥ ca ayam abhipraiti
translated: And this one who says that the faults are non-existent is indeed aiming at this very thing.

analyzed: samāsa antara pakṣa bhāvinaḥ tāvat doṣa anabhyupagama mātreṇa eka prahāra nihatāḥ
translated: Those faults that belong to the alternative of a different compound have been struck down with a single blow by mere acceptance.

analyzed: samāna adhikaraṇa samāsaḥ tu dṛṣṭa tvāt na anupapannaḥ
translated: But the co-referential compound is not impossible because it is seen.

original: tathā hy artho nāntararīyako 'pi syād anityalakṣaṇo 'nāntarīyako 'pi syāt nityalakṣaṇaḥ /
analyzed: tathā hi arthaḥ nāntararīyakaḥ syāt anitya lakṣaṇaḥ nāntarīyakaḥ api syāt nitya lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: For thus, the meaning may be inseparable, the characteristic of the impermanent may be inseparable, and the characteristic of the permanent may be inseparable.

analyzed: tatas eka pada vyabhicārāt api sāmānādhikaraṇyam aviruddham
translated: Therefore, even from the deviation of a single word, the co-reference is not contradictory.

original: atha tvanmate nityo nāmāsty eva kalpaviparivarti tāvad asti /
analyzed: atha tvad mate nityaḥ nāma asti eva kalpa viparivarti tāvat asti
translated: But if you maintain that the eternal does exist, then it exists during the revolution of the aeons.

analyzed: tatas eva etat upalapsyate
translated: Therefore, this will be understood from that alone.

analyzed: anyathā ayam anitya dhvaniḥ kam vyavacchiṃdyāt
translated: Otherwise, this non-eternal time would exclude what?

original: ca tathābhūtasya kṣaṇikatvasya kenacid aniṣṭeḥ🔽tathābhūtavyavacchedāt naivākṣaṇikajñānavāstvityādau prayoge 'yam akṣaṇikadhvaniḥ kaṃ vyavacchiṃdyāt /
analyzed: bauddha abhimatasya ca tathābhūtasya kṣaṇika tvasya kenacid aniṣṭeḥ  tathābhūta vyavacchedāt na eva akṣaṇika jñāna vāstu ityādau prayoge yam akṣaṇika dhvaniḥ kam
translated: Because no one desires such a momentary nature,🔽in a proof such as The non-momentary is not real, what would this non-momentary time exclude?

original: atha nāntarīyaka iti pūrvam ukte 'rthasyāvagatatvāt kim arthapadena yenaivaṃ samāsaś cintyeta /
analyzed: atha nāntarīyakaḥ iti pūrvam ukte rthasya avagata tvāt kim artha padena yena evam samāsaḥ cintyeta
translated: But if it is said to be an invariable concomitant, since the meaning has already been understood from the previous statement, what is the purpose of the word meaning, by which such a compound would be considered?

original: hantākāśādiśabdenaiva pūrvabhāvinā dravyādirūpasyāvagatatvāt kiṃ dravyādiśabdena na tatrāpi tathā samāsaḥ syāt /
analyzed: hanta ākāśa ādi śabdena eva pūrva bhāvinā dravya ādi rūpasya avagata tvāt kim dravya ādi śabdena tatra api tathā samāsaḥ syāt
translated: Since the nature of substance and so on has already been understood from the previous word space and so on, what is the purpose of the word substance and so on? It would not be compounded in that way even there.

original: tad evam ādau ya eva te parihāraḥ samādhir bhasa me 'pi bha
analyzed: tat evam ādau yaḥ eva te parihāraḥ samādhiḥ me pi bha
translated: Thus, the same objection and solution that apply at the beginning will apply to me as well.

analyzed: viṣyati iti yat kiñcid etat
translated: So this is just something.

original: yat tu pṛthivī dravyam ity atrobhayapadavyabhicāraṃ darśayitvā sarvatrobhayapadavyabhicārād eva samānādhikaraṇaḥ samāso bhavatīti darśitaṃ
analyzed: yat tu pṛthivī dravyam iti atra ubhaya pada vyabhicāram darśayitvā sarvatra ubhaya pada vyabhicārāt eva samāna adhikaraṇaḥ samāsaḥ bhavati iti darśitam  /
translated: But when it is shown that there is deviation of both words in the case of the substance earth, and it is shown that the compound is co-extensive everywhere due to deviation of both words,

analyzed: tat yogaḥ tat pāpīyaḥ  ākāśa dravyam diś dravyam kāla dravyam
translated: that is worse.🔽The substance space, the substance direction, the substance time.

analyzed: sāmānya padārthaḥ
translated: The universal category.
The particular category.

original: ṣaṭpadārthaḥ yācakapuruṣa ityādau ubhayapadavyabhicārasya brahmaṇāpi vibhāvayitum aśakyatvāt sāmānādhikaraṇyasya ca darśanāt
translated: In cases like the beggar-man, it is impossible for even Brahmā to show deviation of both words, and co-extensiveness is seen.

original: na hy eṣām ākāśādīnāṃ sāmānyaṃ kenacid apyate saṃgacchate vā yenākāśādiśabdānām ākāśākāśatvādyanekārthavṛttitvād ubhayapadavyabhicāre samānādhikaraṇaḥ
analyzed: na hi eṣām ākāśa ādīnām sāmānyam kenacid apyate saṃgacchate vā yena ākāśa ādi śabdānām ākāśa ākāśa tva ādi aneka artha vṛtti tvāt ubhaya pada vyabhicāre samāna adhikaraṇaḥ
translated: For no common property of these space etc. is obtained or connected by anyone, by which the words space etc. would have multiple meanings like space-ness of space etc., and due to deviation of both words, the compound would be co-extensive.

analyzed: samāsaḥ syāt
translated: This is not so.

original: ṣaṇṇāṃ kiñcit sāmānyam asti yasyāpy abhidhyād abhidhānād a
